The exclusionary rule, which excludes unlawfully obtained evidence from criminal trials, protects rights guaranteed by the Fourth or Fifth Amendments. The exclusionary rule protects constitutional rights by excluding impermissibly obtained evidence from criminal trials, aiming to deter government misconduct and unwarranted privacy intrusions. It differs from remedies like retrials as it focuses on both retrospectively redressing injustice and prospectively deterring misconduct.
